She was the daughter of Lord Edmund Howard and Joyce Culpeper, cousin to Anne Boleyn, and niece to Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk. Thomas Howard was a prominent politician at Henry's court, and he secured her a place in the household of Henry's fourth wife, Anne of Cleves, where she caught the King's in

entities.title: Henry VIII of England
entities.description: Henry VIII was King of England from 1509 until his death in 1547. Henry is best known for his six marriages, and, in particular, his efforts to have his first marriage annulled. His disagreement with Pope Clement VII about such an annulment led Henry to initiate the English Reformation, separating the Church of England from papal authority. He appointed himself Supreme Head of the Church of Englan

heading: Deaths
txt: Benvenuto Cellini, Italian painter and sculptor (b. 1500)

entities.title: Benvenuto Cellini
entities.description: Benvenuto Cellini was an Italian goldsmith, sculptor, draftsman, soldier, musician, and artist who also wrote poetry and a famous autobiography.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfonso Salmeron, Spanish priest and scholar (b. 1515)

entities.title: Alfonso Salmeron
entities.description: Alfonso (Alphonsus) Salmerón was a Spanish biblical scholar, a Catholic priest, and one of the first Jesuits.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Nowell, English clergyman and theologian (b. 1507)

entities.title: Alexander Nowell
entities.description: Alexander Nowell was an Anglican priest and theologian. He served as Dean of St Paul's during much of Elizabeth I's reign, and is now remembered for his catechisms.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles X Gustav, king of Sweden (b. 1622)

entities.title: Charles X Gustav of Sweden
entities.description: Charles X Gustav, also Carl Gustav, was King of Sweden from 1654 until his death. He was the son of John Casimir, Count Palatine of Zweibrücken-Kleeburg and Catherine of Sweden. After his father's death he also succeeded him as Pfalzgraf. He was married to Hedwig Eleonora of Holstein-Gottorp, who bore his son and successor, Charles XI. Charles X Gustav was the second Wittelsbach king of Sweden aft

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth Stuart, queen of Bohemia (b. 1596)

entities.title: Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia
entities.description: Elizabeth Stuart was Electress of the Palatinate and briefly Queen of Bohemia as the wife of Frederick V of the Palatinate. Because her husband's reign in Bohemia and Palatinate lasted for just one winter, Elizabeth is often referred to as the "Winter Queen".

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Caspar Kerll, German organist and composer (b. 1627)

entities.title: Johann Caspar Kerll
entities.description: Johann Caspar Kerll was a German baroque composer and organist. He is also known as Kerl, Gherl, Giovanni Gasparo Cherll and Gaspard Kerle.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Wotton, English linguist and scholar (b. 1666)

entities.title: William Wotton
entities.description: William Wotton was an English theologian, classical scholar and linguist. He is chiefly remembered for his remarkable abilities in learning languages and for his involvement in the Quarrel of the Ancients and the Moderns. In Wales he is remembered as the collector and first translator of the ancient Welsh laws.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cotton Mather, American minister and author (b. 1663)

entities.title: Cotton Mather
entities.description: Cotton Mather was a New England Puritan minister, prolific author, and pamphleteer. One of the most important intellectual figures in English-speaking colonial America, Mather is remembered today chiefly for his Magnalia Christi Americana (1702) and other works of history, for his scientific contributions to plant hybridization and to the promotion of inoculation as a means of preventing smallpox

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles-René d'Hozier, French historian and author (b. 1640)

entities.title: Charles-René d'Hozier
entities.description: Charles-René d'Hozier was a French historical commentator. The younger son of Pierre d'Hozier, he was the true continuator of his father.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Joseph Fux, Austrian composer and theorist (b. 1660)

entities.title: Johann Joseph Fux
entities.description: Johann Joseph Fux was an Austrian composer, music theorist and pedagogue of the late Baroque era. His most enduring work is not a musical composition but his treatise on counterpoint, Gradus ad Parnassum, which has become the single most influential book on the Palestrinian style of Renaissance polyphony.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Joseph Boscovich, Croatian physicist, astronomer, mathematician, and philosopher (b. 1711)

entities.title: Roger Joseph Boscovich
entities.description: Roger Joseph Boscovich was a physicist, astronomer, mathematician, philosopher, diplomat, poet, theologian, Jesuit priest, and a polymath from the Republic of Ragusa. He studied and lived in Italy and France where he also published many of his works.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Gravier, comte de Vergennes, French lawyer and politician, Foreign Minister of France (b. 1717)

entities.title: Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs (France)
entities.description: The Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs is the ministry of the Government of France that handles France's foreign relations. Since 1855, its headquarters have been located at 37 Quai d'Orsay, close to the National Assembly. The term Quai d'Orsay is often used as a metonym for the ministry. Its cabinet minister, the Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs is responsible for the foreign relation

heading: Deaths
txt: Samuel Ashe, American lawyer and politician, 9th Governor of North Carolina (b. 1725)

entities.title: Samuel Ashe (North Carolina governor)
entities.description: Samuel Ashe was the ninth Governor of the U.S. state of North Carolina from 1795 to 1798. He was also one of the first three judges of the North Carolina Superior Court in 1787.

entities.title: Governor of North Carolina
entities.description: The governor of North Carolina is the head of state and head of government of the U.S. state of North Carolina. The governor directs the executive branch of the government and is the commander in chief of the military forces of the state. The current governor, Democrat Roy Cooper took office on January 1, 2017, and had a public swearing-in ceremony on January 7, 2017.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Rogers Clark, American general (b. 1752)

entities.title: George Rogers Clark
entities.description: George Rogers Clark was an American surveyor, soldier, and militia officer from Virginia who became the highest-ranking American patriot military officer on the northwestern frontier during the American Revolutionary War. He served as leader of the militia in Kentucky throughout much of the war. He is best known for his celebrated captures of Kaskaskia (1778) and Vincennes (1779) during the Illino

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Ludwig von der Pahlen, Russian general and politician, Governor-General of Baltic provinces (b. 1745)

entities.title: Peter Ludwig von der Pahlen
entities.description: Peter Ludwig Graf von der Pahlen was a Baltic German courtier and general who played a pivotal role in the assassination of Emperor Paul. He became a general in 1798, a count in 1799, and was the Military Governor of St. Petersburg from 1798 to 1801.

entities.title: Governor-General of Baltic provinces
entities.description: Governor-General of the Baltic provinces or Governor-General of Estonia, Livonia, and Courland was the military commander of the Riga Military District and the highest administrator of the Baltic governorates of Estonia, Livonia and Courland sporadically under Russian rule in the 19th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Berry, English admiral (b. 1768)

entities.title: Edward Berry
entities.description: Rear Admiral Sir Edward Berry, 1st Baronet, KCB was an officer in Britain's Royal Navy primarily known for his role as flag captain of Rear Admiral Horatio Nelson's ship HMS Vanguard at the Battle of the Nile, prior to his knighthood in 1798. He had a long and prestigious naval career and also commanded HMS Agamemnon at the Battle of Trafalgar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mariano José de Larra, Spanish journalist and author (b. 1809)

entities.title: Mariano José de Larra
entities.description: Mariano José de Larra was a Spanish romantic writer and journalist best known for his numerous essays and his infamous suicide. His works were often satirical and critical of the 19th-century Spanish society, and focused on both the politics and customs of his time.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henrik Steffens, Norwegian-German philosopher and poet (b. 1773)

entities.title: Henrik Steffens
entities.description: Henrik Steffens, was a German philosopher, scientist, and poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Costache Caragiale, Romanian actor and manager (b. 1815)

entities.title: Costache Caragiale
entities.description: Costache Caragiale was a Romanian actor and theatre manager who had an important role in the development of the Romanian theatre.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Wagner, German composer (b. 1813)

entities.title: Richard Wagner
entities.description: Wilhelm Richard Wagner was a German composer, theatre director, polemicist, and conductor who is chiefly known for his operas. Unlike most opera composers, Wagner wrote both the libretto and the music for each of his stage works. Initially establishing his reputation as a composer of works in the romantic vein of Carl Maria von Weber and Giacomo Meyerbeer, Wagner revolutionised opera through his c

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Baptiste Lamy, French-American archbishop (b. 1814)

entities.title: Jean-Baptiste Lamy
entities.description: Jean-Baptiste Lamy, was an American Roman Catholic prelate who served as the first Archbishop of Santa Fe, New Mexico. Willa Cather's novel Death Comes for the Archbishop is based on his life and career.

heading: Deaths
txt: Provo Wallis, Canadian-English admiral (b. 1791)

entities.title: Provo Wallis
entities.description: Admiral of the Fleet Sir Provo William Parry Wallis, was a Royal Navy officer. As a junior officer, following the capture of USS Chesapeake by the frigate HMS Shannon during the War of 1812, the wounding of HMS Shannon's captain and the death of her first lieutenant in the action, he served as the temporary captain of HMS Shannon as she returned to Halifax, Nova Scotia, with Chesapeake.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ignacio Manuel Altamirano, Mexican intellectual and journalist (b. 1834)

entities.title: Ignacio Manuel Altamirano
entities.description: Ignacio Manuel Altamirano Basilio was a Mexican radical liberal writer, journalist, teacher and politician. He wrote Clemencia (1869), which is often considered to be the first modern Mexican novel.

heading: Deaths
txt: Konstantin Savitsky, Russian painter (b. 1844)

entities.title: Konstantin Savitsky
entities.description: Konstantin Apollonovich Savitsky was a Russian realist painter born in the city of Taganrog in the village Frankovka or Baronovka, named after former governor Otto Pfeilizer-Frank. Today this area is occupied by the Taganrog Iron and Steel Factory TAGMET.

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Gottschalk, Danish painter (b. 1866)

entities.title: Albert Gottschalk
entities.description: Albert Gottschalk was a Danish painter. He had a close connection, personally and artistically, to the poets Johannes Jørgensen, Viggo Stuckenberg and Sophus Claussen.

heading: Deaths
txt: József Pusztai, Slovene-Hungarian poet and journalist (b. 1864)

entities.title: József Pusztai
entities.description: József Pusztai was a Slovene writer, poet, journalist, teacher, and cantor in Hungary. He was also known under the pen name Tibor Andorhegyi.

entities.description: Otakar Batlička was a Czech adventurer, journalist, ham (amateur) radio operator, and member of the Czech-based Nazi resistance group Obrana Národa during World War II.

entities.description: The president of Brazil, officially the President of the Federative Republic of Brazil or simply the President of the Republic, is both the head of state and the head of government of Brazil. The president leads the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the Brazilian Armed Forces. The presidential system was established in 1889, upon the proclamation of the re

heading: Deaths
txt: Rafael Sabatini, Italian-English novelist and short story writer (b. 1875)

entities.title: Rafael Sabatini
entities.description: Rafael Sabatini was an Italian-English writer of romance and adventure novels.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Lloyd C. Douglas
entities.description: Lloyd Cassel Douglas was an American minister and author.

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Josephine Tey was a pseudonym used by Elizabeth MacKintosh, a Scottish author. Her novel The Daughter of Time was a detective work investigating the role of Richard III of England in the death of the Princes in the Tower, and named as the greatest crime novel of all time by the Crime Writers' Association. Her first play Richard of Bordeaux, written under another pseudonym Gordon Daviot, starred Jo

heading: Deaths
txt: Agnes Macphail, Canadian educator and politician (b. 1890)

entities.title: Agnes Macphail
entities.description: Agnes Campbell Macphail was a Canadian politician from Ontario who was the country's first female Member of Parliament. First elected to the House of Commons of Canada in 1921, she served as an MP until 1940. heading: Deaths
txt: Jan Łukasiewicz, Polish mathematician and philosopher (b. 1878)

entities.title: Jan Łukasiewicz
entities.description: Jan Łukasiewicz was a Polish logician and philosopher who is best known for Polish notation and Łukasiewicz logic. He was born in Lemberg, a city in the Galician Kingdom of Austria-Hungary. His work centred on philosophical logic, mathematical logic and history of logic. He thought innovatively about traditional propositional logic, the principle of non-contradiction and the law of excluded middle

heading: Deaths
txt: Christabel Pankhurst, English activist, co-founded the Women's Social and Political Union (b. 1880)

entities.title: Christabel Pankhurst
entities.description: Dame Christabel Harriette Pankhurst, was a British suffragette born in Manchester, England. A co-founder of the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU), she directed its militant actions from exile in France from 1912 to 1913. In 1914 she supported the war against Germany. After the war she moved to the United States, where she worked as an evangelist for the Second Adventist movement.

entities.title: Women's Social and Political Union
entities.description: The Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) was a women-only political movement and leading militant organisation campaigning for women's suffrage in the United Kingdom from 1903 to 1918. Known from 1906 as the suffragettes, its membership and policies were tightly controlled by Emmeline Pankhurst and her daughters Christabel and Sylvia.

heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Paulino Alcántara
entities.description: Paulino Alcántara Riestrá was a Filipino and Spanish football player and manager who played as a forward. He spent most of his playing career at FC Barcelona and also represented Catalonia, the Philippines and Spain.

entities.description: Yoshisuke Aikawa   was a Japanese entrepreneur, businessman, and politician, noteworthy as the founder and first president of the Nissan zaibatsu (1931-1945), one of Japan's most powerful business conglomerates around the time of the Second World War.

entities.title: Nissan Motor Company
entities.description: The Nissan Motor Company, Ltd.  is a Japanese multinational automobile manufacturer headquartered in Nishi-ku, Yokohama, Japan. The company sells its vehicles under the Nissan, Infiniti, and Datsun brands. The company traces its name to the Nissan zaibatsu, now called Nissan Group.

entities.description: Mae Marsh was an American film actress with a career spanning over 50 years.

entities.title: Marinus Jan Granpré Molière
entities.description: Marinus Jan Granpré Molière was a Dutch architect. His work was part of the architecture event in the art competition at the 1924 Summer Olympics.

entities.title: André Beaufre
entities.description: André Beaufre  was a French Army officer and military strategist who attained the rank of Général d'Armée before his retirement in 1961.

entities.title: President of Nigeria
entities.description: The president of the Federal Republic of Nigeria is the head of state and head of government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. The president of Nigeria is also the commander-in-chief of the Nigerian Armed Forces. The president is elected in national elections which take place every four years. The offices, powers, and titles of the head of state and the head of government were officially merged

entities.title: David Janssen
entities.description: David Janssen was an American film and television actor who is best known for his starring role as Richard Kimble in the television series The Fugitive (1963–1967). Janssen also had the title roles in three other series: Richard Diamond, Private Detective; Harry O; and O'Hara, U.S. Treasury.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cheong Eak Chong, Singaporean entrepreneur (b. 1888)

entities.title: Cheong Eak Chong
entities.description: Cheong Eak Chong, or, under his given name, Zhong Mingxuan, was a Chinese-Singaporean entrepreneur of She minority ethnic descent. He was born in Anxi County in Fujian in 1888, but left China in 1921 for Singapore. heading: Deaths
txt: Yuri Ivask, Russian-American poet and critic (b. 1907)

entities.title: Yuri Ivask
entities.description: Yuri Pavlovich Ivask was a Russian, Estonian poet and literary critic; in his later years an American scholar of Russian literature.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wayne Hays, American lieutenant and politician (b. 1911)

entities.title: Wayne Hays
entities.description: Wayne Levere Hays was an American politician who served as a U.S. Representative of Ohio, in the Democratic Party, from 1949 to 1976. He resigned from Congress after a much-publicized sex scandal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arno Breker, German sculptor and illustrator (b. 1900)

entities.title: Arno Breker
entities.description: Arno Breker was a German architect and sculptor who is best known for his public works in Nazi Germany, where they were endorsed by the authorities as the antithesis of degenerate art. One of his better known statues is Die Partei, representing the spirit of the Nazi Party that flanked one side of the carriage entrance to Albert Speer's new Reich Chancellery.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolay Bogolyubov, Ukrainian-Russian mathematician and physicist (b. 1909)

entities.title: Nikolay Bogolyubov
entities.description: Nikolay Nikolayevich Bogolyubov, also transliterated as Bogoliubov and Bogolubov, was a Soviet mathematician and theoretical physicist known for a significant contribution to quantum field theory, classical and quantum statistical mechanics, and the theory of dynamical systems; he was the recipient of the 1992 Dirac Prize.

heading: Deaths
txt: Martin Balsam, American actor (b. 1919)

entities.title: Martin Balsam
entities.description: Martin Henry Balsam was an American actor who had a prolific career in character roles in film, in theatre, and on television.

txt: Robert Klark Graham, American eugenicist and businessman (b. 1906)

entities.title: Robert Klark Graham
entities.description: Robert Klark Graham was an American eugenicist and businessman who made millions by developing shatterproof plastic eyeglass lenses and who later founded the Repository for Germinal Choice, a sperm bank for geniuses, in the hope of implementing a eugenics program.

txt: Ricardo Arias Calderón, Panamanian politician (b. 1933)

entities.title: Ricardo Arias Calderón
entities.description: Ricardo Arias Calderón was a Panamanian politician who served as First Vice President from 1989 to 1992. A Roman Catholic who studied at Yale and the Sorbonne, Arias returned to Panama in the 1960s to work for political reform. txt: Henrik, Prince Consort of Denmark, French-born Danish royal (b. 1934)

entities.title: Henrik, Prince Consort of Denmark
entities.description: Prince Henrik of Denmark was the husband of Margrethe II of Denmark. He served as her royal consort from 14 January 1972 until his death.
